content.description: A bit tough on the skin but the movement is fun. Not quite as easy of a warmup as the others, but still good for acclimating to the rock type and to prepare for other problems.
content.protection: 1 big pad works fine, but because of the rocky landing, two pads might be ideal.
content.location: Sit-start matching on the triangular protrusion at the very bottom of the boulder. Everything is on, just go up and traverse right. Top out at the highest point of the boulder, on the right side of the face.

content.description: Start matched on the low rail on the right side of the boulder. Dyno to the top is about v5, bumping left first is softer.
content.protection: One big pad is enough but two might be ideal due to the rocky landing.
content.location: Right side of the slant boulder

content.description: Same start and finish as the upper line, except goes rightwards on the face rather than up the lip. It might seem slightly contrived to fully ignore the lip, but when going right after the start, it is pretty much pointless to reach the lip prior to the topout anyways. Regardless, this problem has some of the best moves out of these boulders.We're not very confident about the grade, please suggest what you think!Video: youtu.be/o9b5LuwS9zo
content.protection: 1 big pad works fine, but because of the rocky landing, two pads might be ideal.
content.location: Sit-start matching on the triangular protrusion at the very bottom of the boulder. Go directly right with the crimp. Once you have the sidepull crack, get up to the crimps at the top of the seam and then make a big final move towards the jugs at the highest point of the boulder to top out.

content.description: When you're hanging on this boulder, it feels sort of like gravity pulls you diagonally.All the holds are very coarse and offer lots of friction, except for the smooth vertical crack.
